title: arithmetic
content:
arithmeticUS /əˈrɪθ.mə.tɪk/ UK /əˈrɪθ.mə.tɪk/
n. the part of mathematics that involves the adding and multiplying, etc. of numbers:
an arithmetic test
arithmetical
arithmetically
add\subtract\multiply\divide

title: bowl
content:
bowl
n. a round container that is open at the top and is deep enough to hold fruit, sugar, etc A salad bowl A bowl of soup

n. a dish made of layers of different foods served in a bowl


The healthy acai bowl has three layers: a blended, yogurt-like bottom of acai and hemp milk, homemade granola in themiddle, and fresh bananas and strawberries on top.

Super Bowl in the U.S., a game of football played each year between the winners of the two leagues (= groups) in orderto decide which is the best team in the country

spoon
an object consisting of a round, hollow part and a handle, used for mixing, serving, and eating food A soup spoon ateaspoon

to move something, especially food, using a spoon


He spooned milk into the baby’s open mouth.
dish
a container, flatter than a bowl

the dishes


all the plates, glasses, knives, forks, etc. that have been used during a meal
chopstick
one of a pair of narrow sticks that are used for eating East Asian food

Chinese use chopsticks to eat food.

title: consequence
content:
consequenceUK  /ˈkɒn.sɪ.kwəns/ US  /ˈkɑːn.sə.kwəns/
n. a result of a particular action or situation, often one that is bad or not convenient
For someone who is old and weak, the consequences of a broken hip can be serious.
consequently
as a result

title: convolution
content:
convolution/ˌkɑːn.vəˈluː.ʃən/

n. a twist

endless convolutions

n. something that makes an explanation, story, etc. complicated and difficult to understand

n. one of the many folds of the surface of the brain


neuralUS /ˈnʊr.əl/ UK /ˈnjʊə.rəl/

adj. involving a nerve or the system of nerves that includes the brain

network
n. a large system consisting of many similar parts that are connected together to allow movement or communicationbetween or along the parts, or between the parts and a control center:

CNNConvolutional Neural Network

title: definite
content:
definiteUS  /ˈdef.ən.ət/ UK  /ˈdef.ɪ.nət/
adj. fixed, certain, or clear:
Do you have a definite aim for your life?
n. something that is certain to happen:
She’s a definite for the Olympic team.
definite article: 
the grammatical name for the word “the” in English, or the words in other languages that have a similar use

title: deviation
content:
DeviationUK  /ˌdiː.viˈeɪ.ʃən/ US  /ˌdiː.viˈeɪ.ʃən/
the action of doing something that is different from the usual or common way of behaving
standard deviation

title: exaggerated
content:
exaggeratedUK  /ɪɡˈzædʒ.ə.reɪ.tɪd/ US  /ɪɡˈzædʒ.ə.reɪ.t̬ɪd/
seeming larger, more important, better, or worse than it really is:
The slimming effect of wearing black has been greatly exaggerated.
Neymar admits exaggerated reactions at World Cup.

title: gimbal
content:
gimbalUS  /ˈɡɪm.bəl/ UK  /ˈɡɪm.bəl/
n. a device with a circular part that turns around a fixed central axis (= straight line), used for keeping a compass, camera, or other piece of equipment in position when it is inside a moving vehicle or object
In a spacecraft, rocket engines are usually mounted on a pair of gimbals.
A remote controlled Gimbal Car.

title: incident
content:
incidentUS  /ˈɪn.sɪ.dənt/ UK  /ˈɪn.sɪ.dənt/
n. an event that is either unpleasant or unusual
What can I do when fire incident happen?

adj. touching or hitting the surface of something
The angle of incident ray equals angle of reflected ray.

title: insight
content:
insightUK  /ˈɪn.saɪt/ US  /ˈɪn.saɪt/
(the ability to have) a clear, deep, and sometimes sudden understanding of a complicated problem or situation:It was an interesting book, full of fascinating insights into human relationships.

title: mock
content:
mock
v. to laugh at someone, often by copying them in a funny but unkind wayPlease stop mocking me!

v. to make something appear stupid or not effective


Donald Trump Mocks Disabled Reporter.

adj. not real but appearing or pretending to be exactly like something

She appears mock surprise.

n. an exam taken at school for practice before a real exam

You will have your mocks during the first two weeks of March.

title: quotient
content:
quotientUS /ˈkwoʊ.ʃənt/ UK /ˈkwəʊ.ʃənt/

n. the result of dividing one number by anotherThe quotient of 24 dividing 4 is 6.
n. the degree, rate, or amount of somethinghappiness quotient

title: Stages_of_life
content:
Stages of life
Be born
Start school
Make friends
Graduate
Get a job
Fall in love
Get married
Have a baby
Divorce
Retire
Make a will
Die

title: supervise
content:
superviseUK  /ˈsuː.pə.vaɪz/ US  /ˈsuː.pɚ.vaɪz/
v. to watch a person or activity to make certain that everything is dong correctly, safely.

She supervises 75 kids in this school.

supervision
City schools were placed under state supervision last week.

supervisory
He applied for a supervisory position in the bank.

###supervisor

I have to get off the phone - my supervisor just walked into the office.

title: symptom
content:
symptomUK  /ˈsɪmp.təm/ US  /ˈsɪmp.təm/
any feeling of illness or physical or mental change that is caused by a particular disease:
Symptoms of COVID-19: fever, shortness of breath and cough.

title: transform
content:
transformUS  /trænsˈfɔːrm/ UK  /trænsˈfɔːm/
v. to change completely the appearance or character of something or someone, especially so that that thing or person is improved
eg:
the power of art to transform experience.
The reorganization will transform the entertainment industry.

transformerI’m a fun of Transformers.
